data.text: Every saddle you try will need a breaking in period. I've been riding the same Brooks saddle for 20 years. I love it. Some people don't have the patience to get used to longer riding. You have adapt to the saddle.

data.text: I've had a enlarged prostate four years, I'm 66. But it has never hurt, does yours?
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: No, but following an incident where I became severely dehydrated and the ensuing plumbing problems, combined with an enlarged prostate, my doc advised that I quit riding. Compromise is a prostate friendly saddle to avoid irritating plumbing problems..
data.author: Wallace Bromberg Jr

data.text: Properly fitted bike (pay a professional if you have issues), and a strong core that properly supports upper body weight. And avoid excessive padding, as you will sink too deep, and get pressured and bit. For bump absorption, a good seat should flex, about like a firm booty, and your only points of contact should be the sitbones. Keep that in mind as you shop.
data.author: Ken Hill

data.text: I will turn 60 this year. I have a lot of extended tours and Ragbrai's under my belt. I wish I found the Brooks B17 years ago. I bought a new touring bike that had a Brooks on it, I liked it so much, that I bought another for my racing bike. It looks uncomfortable, but looks are deceiving

data.text: ISM replaced my Brooks saddle. Eliminates all the center pressure. Found to reduce impotence in Swedish bike cops who were spending long days riding traditional saddle. I only ride the Brooks saddle for short rides on cruiser bike now because it looks cool.
